div.p:
XII. 231 271
in all probability possess the
imperishability which forms
so remarkable a feature in
the entire African race

Daintree & Co. When converts are made
from heathenism by modern
missionaries it becomes
an interesting question whether
their faith possesses the
elements of permanence
or is only an exotic too
tender for self propagation
when the fostering care
of the foreign cultivators
is withdrawn - If habits
of self reliance are not both
sedulously cultivated and
opportunities given for
the exercise of that virtue
the most promising converts
are apt to become like
spoiled children - In Madagascar
a few Christians were
left with nothing but the
bible in their hands
and though exposed to
persecution and even
death itself as the penalty
of adherence to their profession
they increased tenfold
in numbers and are if
possible more decided
christi believers now than
232 272
they were when by an edict of
the queen of that island the
missionaries ceased their
teaching -

In South Africa such
an experiment could not
be made for such a variety
of Christian sects have followed
the footsteps of the London
Missionary Societysthe London Missionary Society's successful
career that converts of one
denomination if left to themselves
their own resources are eagerly
adopted by another and are
thus more likely to become
spoiled children than trained
to the manly Christian virtues

Another element of weakness
in the part of the missionary
field is the fact of Missionary
Societies considering the Colony
a proper sphere for their peculiar
operations - In addition to a
well organized and efficient
Dutch Reformed establishedEstablished
Church we have schools for
secular instruction maintained
by Government in every
village of any extent in
the Colony, we have a number
of other sects as the Wesleyans
Episcopalians Moravians
all piously labouring at the
same good work Now
233 273
it is deeply to be regretted that
so much honest zeal
should be so lavishly expended
in a district whenever there
is so little scope for success
When we hear an agent
of one sect urging his
friends at home to aid
him quickly to occupy some
unimportant nook because
if it is not speedily laid
hold of he will "not
have room for the sole of
his foot" one cannot help
longing that both he and
his friends should direct
their noble aspirations to
the millions of true Heathen
in the regions beyond - and
no longer continue to make
the extremity of the continent
as it were into a dam
of benevolence

I would earnestly
recommend all young
missionaries to go at once
on to the real heathen and
never to be content with
what has been made ready
to his hands by men of greater
enterprise - The idea of
making model christians
of the young need not be
234 274
be entertained by any one who is
secretly convinced as most
men who know their own
hearts are that he is not a
model Christian himself Our
own elevation has been the
work of ages and remembering
this we shall not indulge in
overwrought expectations as
to what those who have inherited
the degradation of ages, in
our day may become -

And the principle might
be adopted by missionary
Societies that one ordinary
missionariesmissionary's lifetime of teaching
should be considered an
ample supply of foreign
teaching for any tribe in a
thinly peopled country
A missionary is soon
known to be supported by
his friends at home - and
though the salary is but a
bare subsistence to Africans
it seems an enormous sum
and being unable to appreciate
the motives by which he is
actuated they consider them-
-selves entitled to various
services at his hands and
themselves defrauded if they
are not duly rendered - This
feeling is all the stronger
235 275
when a young man instead
of going boldly to the real
heathen settles down in
a comfortable house and
garden prepared by those
who into whose labours
he has entered - A remedy
for this might be found
in appropriating the houses
and gardens raised by
the missionariesmissionaries' to their own
hands to their own families
It is ridiculous to call
such places as Kuruman
for instance "Missionary
property" This beautiful
station was made what
it is not by English money
bybut by the sweat & toil
of fathers whose children
have notwithstanding
no place on earth they
can call a home - And
in all probability it is
the strong built mission
premises are destined to
be the home of a Boer
and the stately stone
church his cattle pen -

Protestant missionaries
of every denomination in
South Africa all agree in
one point that no mere
profession of Christianity is
236 276
sufficient to entitle the converts
to the Christian name - They are all
anxious to place the bible in
their hands and with ability
to read that there can be little
doubt as to the future - We
believe Christianity to be divine
and equal to all it has to
perform - then let the good
seed be widely sown no
and no matter to what sect the converts
may belong the harvest will
be glorious - Nothing that
I have said must be in-
-terpreted as indicative of
feelings inimical to any body
of Christians for I never as
a missionary felt myself
to be either Presbyterian
Episcopalian or IndependantIndependent
or called upon in any way
to love less one sect than
another - My earnest desire
is that those who really have
the best interests of the heathen
at heart should go to them
and assuredly in Africa at
least selfdenyingself-denying labours
among real heathen will
be appreciated - Christians
have never yet dealt fairly
by the heathen and been
disappointed

237 When Sechele understood
that we could no longer 277
remain with him at Kolobeng
he sent his children to Mr
Moffat at Kuruman for
instruction in all the know-
-ledge of the white men - Mr MMoffat
very liberally received at once
an accession ^ of five to his famiily
[with their attendants - Before
Having I wasbeen detained about a
fortnight wby the breaking
of a waggon wheel
238 278
I was Providentially prevented
from being present at the
attack of the Boers on
the Bakwains news of
which were about the end
of that time brought by Ma-
-sebele the wife of Sechele -
She had herself been hidden
in a cleft of rock over which
a number of boersBoers were
firing - Her infant began to
cry and terrified lest ^ this should attact
attract ^ their
attention of the men the muzzles
of whose guns appeared
at every discharge over
her head, she took off her
armlets as play things to ^ quiet the Child still her
She brought a letter which
tells its own tale to Revd RRobert Moffat
" nearly literally translated it runswas
as follows

"Friend of my heart's love and
of all the confidence of my heart
I am, Sechele, I am undone
by the Boers who attacked me (though
I had no guilt with them) - They
demanded that I should be
in their kingdom and I refused
They demanded that I should
prevent the English & Griquas
from passing - (Northwards)
I replied these are my friends
and I can prevent no one (of them)
They came on Saturday and
239 279
I besoughtasked them not to fight on
Sunday but I besought them
not to fight on Sunday and
they assented - They began on
Monday morning ^ at twilight and fired
with all their might and burned
the town with fire & scattered us
They killed sixty of my people
and captured women and
children and men - And the
mother of BaleringBaleriling they also
took prisoner - they took
all the cattle and all the goods
of the Bakwains - And the
house of LivingstonLivingstone they
plundered taking away all
his goods - The number of
waggons they had was eighty
five and a cannon and
after they had stolen my
own waggon and that of
Macabe then the number
of their waggons (counting the
cannon as one) was Eighty
four eight - All the goods
of the hunters (certain gentlemen
hunting & exploring in the North)
were burned in the town ---
And of the Boers were killed
twenty eight - Yes - my beloved
friend now my wife goes
to see the children and Kobus
Hae will convey her to you
I am Sechele
the son of Mochoasele"
240 10280
This statement is in exact
accordance with the account
^ given by the
native teacher
Mebalwe and
also that sent by some of the Boers to
the public colonial papers - The
crime of cattle stealing of which
we hear so much near
Caffreland was never ^ alleged attributed
against these people, and if a single case had
ever occurred when I was
in the country I must have
heard of it and would
at once declare it - But the
only crime imputed was in
the papers was "Sechele was getting too saucy!"
The demand made for his
subjection and service in
preventing the English traders
penetrating passing to the North was
kept out of view - As this
was a Caffre war in embryo
it is important to remark
that everything was done
in perfectly orthodox style
These Boers They cou had just been received
as a body into the Dutch Reformed
Church with great solemnity
and concluded a treaty with
Sir George Cathcart by means
of the Commissioners Hogg
and Owen for stipulating
for freedom of access to
the Interior for Englishmen
and that no slavery should
be permitted - But as they
241 281
all believe assert when the
question was put "and what
about the missionaries" - ?
One of the Commissioners jokingly
replied "O you can do as you
like with them - " The consequence
of this indiscretion was the
immediate organization
of the expedition against
Sechele and the destruction
of three mission stations -

The treaty was made with
the Rebel A -Andries W -Wilhelmus Pretorius
The missionaries of two of
these being formally expelled the country afterwards
for mildly remonstrating with the Commandant
Peit Scholtz
at the sight of the Boers
driving crowds of children
while on their very back
from the fight to & from
the waters as is done
with flocks of goats - From
Sechele were taken away
200 of the children most
of whom I could have
identified as belonging
to our schools - These and
hundreds of others are now
bought and sold ^ openly as slaves
in the vicinity of the Colony
My house which had stood
in perfect safety in the
gaurdianshipguardianship of the natives
during the three years of
my Northern & Southern
242 282
journiesjourneys was plundered of
property of the value of upwards
of Â£ 300 - by those who style
distinguish themselves as "Christians" ("Krystilik
menskenChristelike mans") --> and all the blacks
as creature or (swaarte goedswart goedere) -
black property - The books of
a good library my solace
in the wilderness were not
taken away but the leaves
were torn out and thrown
all over the place - The medicine
bottles were smashed - The
clothing, furniture, & utensils
mills tools &c &c being the only
property ^ in their minds worth taking away
I do not now make a
pitiful wail over my losses
for the plundering of a all
my goods was in some
respects an advantage While it was
impossible not
to feel keenly
the ruthless
waste of lexicons
dictionaries
classical &
medical
books &c -
the companions
of my boyhood
It set mey comind completely
free for the North and
I my family being in England
I ^ felt that I had not a single source
of care in my rearbehind me - But
as matter of duty I immediately
volunteered to Sir George
Cathcart to identify the
school children consigned
in opposition to Mr Commissioner
Owen's jocular treaty to hopeless
slavery, and claimed compensation
for the plunder I had suffered
243 283 13
This came too closely upon the
inauguration of his policy
to merit more than the reply
that "such was the fortitude
of war" - I was then in my
way ^ to the North or I should
have raised a question which
could not have been answered
so cavalierly, viz -videlicet As the Boers
were notoriously intent on
the practisce of slave hunting
? DLDavid Livingstone-
(ququery - stet.) and slavery, whether a
policy favourable to this
system notoriously directly
at variance with the general
policy of the English Government
would not subject the
commander himself to refund
the losses thereby sustained
by British subjects, I should
not have succeeded but
I might stethave recievedreceived the
compensation and had the satisfaction of
feeling that I had taught
a great man that it was
scarcely safe to despise the
meanest missionary

A few years modify
our feelings on many
subjects and towards many
men - Long before I returned
from the North Sir George
Cathcart ^ had died bravely fighting
the battles of his country in
the Crimea loved and lamented
244 284
by all - His policy was a mistake
but no one doubts the uprightness
of him intentions and aims -

Very soon after A - ..Andries W -Wilhelmus Pretorius
sent the marauding party
against Kolobeng he too
has been was called away to the Tribunal
of infinite justice - His policy
is justified by the Boers
generally from the text the
instructions to the Jewish warriors
in Deuteronomy xx. 10-14 - Hence
when he died it was send "Blessed
are the dead, who die in the Lord"
I wish he had not "forbid us
to preach unto the gentiles that
they may be saved" -

The report of this outrage
on the Bakwains coupled
as it was with denunciations
against myself for having,
as it was alleged, ^ ^ taught then to kill boersBoers
produced such a panic in
the country ^ that I could not engage
a single native to accompany
me to the North - During
our residence at Kolobeng
no fewer than nine tribes
had been attacked and large
numbers of children carried
off on each occasion - They
compel the tribes already
subjected to them to act as
a shield to them by standing
245 15285
in front and repelling the attempt
of their countrymen to reach
the Boers, while the latter sit
on their horses and coolly
fire over their heads - These
tribes being totally unprovided
with fire-arms - could never
break through the shield and
never was a drop of Boerish
blood shed - The Bakwains
however having purchased
some guns killed twenty
eight Boers - and I recievedreceived
the credit of the difference
between the attacks of the nine
aforementioned tribes and
that of Kolobeng - Loud vows of
vengeance were uttered against
my head and threats of instant
pursuit by a large party on
horseback should I dare to go
into their country to the North and
as these were coupled with
the declaration that the English
Government had given over
the whole of the native tribes
to their rule and would assist
them in their entire subjugation
by preventing firearms
and ammunition from entering
the country except to the Boers
it was not to be wondered at
that I was detained for months
at Kuruman from sheer
inability to get waggon drivers
246 286
The English name from being
honoured and respected all
over the country because
somewhat more than suspected
and as the policy of depriving
these friendly tribes of the
means of defence is always
adduced by the Boers as
proof positive of the wish
of the English that they
should subjugate the independent
Bechuana tribes the conduct
of a Government they
always thought the paragon
of justice & friendship is
totally incomprehensible
They can neither defend themselves
against their enemies ^ ^ nor shoot the animals by
in the produce of which we wish
them to trade -

I again repeat that the
morality Now the sentiments
of the majority of the Cape people
are not to be judged by
those of its vagabond emigrants
While they are delighted with
the exploration of the Interior
and anxious to promote
the commerce and civilization
of its great population, the
men of whom we now
speak actually fined a
gentleman (Joseph Macabe) EsqrEsquire in the sum of
500 dollars for publishing
247 287
a merely conjectural route
to the Lake Ngami before
it was discovered and kept
him in Prison until the
fine was paid - The reason
assigned was he had gone
into and written about their
country without permission
The boundaries which I have
heard them gravely assign
to their territory are rather
vague for their general
ideas of geography are
derived from an old map
placed in the ^ large old copies of the
Bible left them by their forefathers
This shewsshows the Latitude &
Longitude of the gardenGarden of
Eden - The Pillars of Hercules
and perhaps the bedstead of
of King of Bashan - And
being in the Bible is of
course quite true - Jerusalem
being apparently near forms
the Northern boundary of
Qu:Query this word? the Transvaal Republic

This lamentable ignorance
is the natural consequence of
the position in which they were
left - Not a single minister or
missionary accompanied
them in their emigration but
when Sir Harry Smith routed
them at Boomplaats he most
248 288
nobly resolved to furnish them
with ministers schoolmasters
and nursery gardens for the
promotion of agriculture - and
for their general elevation
Unfortunately his idea was
never carried out - Two Dutch
clergymen went on a ^ hasty tour of
baptizing marrying &c - I happened
to be at the time in the part of the CashanMagaliesberg
mountains ^ which they were visiting
and found my brethren
residing in the house of Mr
Gert Krieger the sub-
commandant who had
first returned from the above
mentioned battle with his
ammunition pouch shot
away, and who had been
noticed significantly by
Sir Harry in a proclamation
for histhe part in the rebellionhe had played in the
rebellion I saw in every house I entered
slave children who had been captured
in the murderous forays
conducted by this very man
I knew their tribes and
my men sometimes knew
their parents and it is a
well known fact that no
Bechuana ever sold a child
and yet when my reverend
brethren returned to the Cape
they published their report
249 289
stating how many hundreds of
converts they has baptized -
How much Christian feeling
rested and "as for slavery
they did not find a vestige
of it" Now admitting the
perfect propriety of their
friendly feelings to people
wandering as sheep without
a shepherd and ^ of their desire to avoid
an exposure of their degradation
would such reports from
89 a missionary concerning
his converts [be considered
honourable He would be
expected to reveal the real
state of his people - I have
now attempted this in reference
to these poor degraded Interior
Boers and in accordance
with the whole of my conduct
when among them I now
say, they assuredly need the
sympathy and aid of their
own church to prevent
them sinking into utter barbarism
No mission to the blacks
ought to be undertaken by
the Dutch untilluntil they have
supplied these children of
pious parents - These now
white savages with the
light of Christianity

When at last I found three
servants willing to risk a
journey to the North and
a man of colour named
George Fleming who had
generously been assssisted by
a mercantile gentleman
of Cape Town to endeavour
to establish a trade with the
MakoloMakololo, had also managed
to get a similar number
we left Kuruman on the
20th NovrNovember and proceeded
on our journey - Our servants
were the worst possible
specimens of those who
imbibe the vices without
the virtues of Europeans
but we had no choice - &
were glad to get away on
any terms -

When we reached Motito
forty miles off we met
Sechele on his way as he
said "to the Queen of England"
Two of his own children
and their mother ^ Mabalerileng were among
the captives and being strongly
embued with the then very
prevalent notion of EnglandsEngland's
justice and generosity he
thought he had ^ had a fair case to lay
before her majesty - He
employed all his eloquence
251 291
and powers of persuasion
to induce me to accompany
him but I excused myself
by the fact of ^ my having sent
my family home for a
different purpose - On
explaining the difficulties
of the way and ^ Endeavouringendeavouring to dissuadingdissuade
him from the attempt on
account of the knowledge
I possessed of Sir George
Cathcart's policy - He
put the pointed question
"Will the Queen not listen
to me supposing I should
reach her"? "I replied "I believe
she would ^ listen but the difficulty
is to get to her". "Well I shall
reach her" expressed his final
determination - Others explained
the difficulties more fully but
nothing could shake his resolution was implacable
When he reached Bloemfontein
he found the army of Sir
George just returning from
a battle in which both parties
claimed the victory and both
were glad that a second
engagement was not tried
The officers not a whit
chagrinnedchagrined by their not over
glorious campaign invited
Sechele to dine with them
heard his story and collected
a handsome ^ sum of money
252 292
to enable him to pursue his
journey to England - As a
single word in favour
of the restoration of the
children of Sechele would
have been a virtual declaration
confession of the failure of
his policy at the very outset
Sir George Cathcart he wisely refrained from
noticing him - Sechele proceeded
to the Cape and his resources
being there expended he was
obliged to return to his own
country again - one thousand
miles distant in a straight
line without accomplishing
the object of his journey -

On his return
he adopted a mode of punishment
he had seen in the colony vizvidelicet
making criminals work
on the public roads - and he
has since I am informed
b made himself the missionary
to his own people - He has
great intelligence, reads well
and is a fluent speaker
Great numbers of the tribes
having under the Boers have
taken refuge under his sway
and he is now greater in
power than he was before
the attack on Kolobeng -

Having parted with Sechele we
skirted along and sometimes
in the Kalahari desert giving the Boers
a wide berth There
had occurred a more than
usual supply of rain in 1852
and that was the period of the completion
of a cycle of eleven or twelve
years at which the same
phenomenon has is reported
to have happened on three
occasions - An unusually
large supply of melons had
appeared and we had the
pleasure of meeting with
J -Joseph Macabe EsqrEsquire returning
from Lake Ngami which
he had succeeded in reaching
by going right across
the Desert from a point
a little to the South of Kolobeng
The accounts of the abundance
of water melons were amply
confirmed by this energetic
traveller for his hadcattle actually
subsisted for a period of
twenty one days on this fluid
found in these alone - and
when at last they reached
a supply of water they did
not seem to care much
about it - Coming to the Lake
from the South East he
crossed the TeageTeoughe and went
round the Northern part of it
We afterwards heard that there had
been some fighting between
these Barolongs and the Boers
and that there had been
capturing of cattle on both sides
These are the first instances
of cattle captured by Bechuanas
I ever heard of -
254 29424
and is the only European
traveller who has actually
seen it all - His estimate
of the extent of the Lake is
higher then that given
by Mr OswelOswell and myself
or about 90 or 100 miles
in circumference - Mr Macabe's
companion
Mahar was
mistaken by
a tribe of Barolongs
for a Boer
and shot as
he approached
their village
When Macabe
came up &
explained the
his nationality
they expressed
the utmost
regret - and
helped to bury
him -. This
was the first
Englishman
in modern recent
times slain
by the Bechuana

Two Another English gentlemen X
crossed and recrossed the
Desert about the same time
and nearly in the same direction
On returning one of them
Captain Shelley inwhile riding
forward on horseback
lost his waypath and was
obliged to find his ^ own way alone
to Kuruman some hundreds
of miles distant - Reaching
that station shirtless and
as brown as a Griqua
he was recievedreceived by Mrs
Moffat as one with a
salutation in Dutch - His
sufferings must have been
far more severe than we
endured; and histhe routes
of Mr he & Mr Macabe
result of both the exertions
of Shelley and Macabe is to
areprove that the general
view of the Desert given
by the natives has been
always substantially correct
